exam.source: National Center For University Entrance Examination
exam.subject: SekaishiB(main exam)

exam:
Center-2003--Main-WorldHistoryB
2003 Academic Year Main Examination: World History B
[1]
Throughout world history, there have been cases in each part of the globe in which the frameworks of coexistence between people of different ethnic groups and religions have broken down, resulting in conflict.At the same time, efforts have been made to seek a path out of conflict, aimed at achieving coexistence.Read the following texts A-C, which relate to conflict and coexistence, and answer the questions (Questions 1-11) below.
(27 points)
AThe Great Wall of China was built along a route that more or less follows the 40th parallel north.On the southern side of the Great Wall, the world of agricultural peoples developed, while the world of nomads and hunting peoples spread out in the arid steppe zone (Mongolian plateau) and woodland zone (Northeastern China) on the northern side.(1) These two northern and southern worlds conducted trade from ancient times and had a relationship based on coexistence, but intense conflicts sometimes broke out.An example of a dynasty that sprang up from the world of the north and unified north and south is the (2)Qing dynasty.The present-day People's Republic of China exists as a multi-ethnic nation centered around the Han people, who form the overwhelming majority, and (3)this can be seen as being the result of it having basically inherited the realm of the final dynasty, the Qing dynasty.
Question 1
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one correct sentence concerning conflict and coexistence between these two worlds, in relation to the underlined portion (1).
１
(1)Under the reign of Emperor Wu, the Han established Jiedushi [military governors] to prevent incursions by nomads.
(2)The Northern Wei eliminated the culture of the Han people and were passive in regard to ruling an agrarian society.
(3)The Tang strove for peace by sending goods such as silver and silk to the Liao and Western Xia each year.
(4)The Ming dispatched troops to the Mongolian plateau during the reign of the Yongle Emperor.
Question 2
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the policy implemented in regard to the various ethnic groups by the dynasty referred to in the underlined portion (2).
２
(1)It promoted a policy of replacing the customs of the Manchu people with those of the Han people.
(2)It placed Tibet under the jurisdiction of the Lifan Yuan [Board for the Administration of Outlying Regions] as a fanbu ["barbarian area"].
(3)It was a patron of scholarship and was also tolerant of anti-Qing sentiment among the Han people.
(4)It abolished the Mingsystem of bureaucracy and did not appoint Han people to important posts in the central government.
Question 3
In regard to the underlined portion (3), from (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that incorrectly describes regions a~d on the map below.
３
(1)Under the Convention of Peking, the Qing ceded a to Russia.
(2)Under the Treaty of Shimonoseki, the Qing affirmed that b was an independent nation.
(3)During the reign of the Kangxi Emperor, the Qing owned c.
(4)At the end of the 19th century, the Qing accepted d as the sphere of influence of the UK.
BThe three religions of Judaism, Christianity and Islam all arose in the region currently called the Middle East and coexisted for a long time under the rule of Muslim powers.This coexistence was also seen in (4)Palestine.However, amid intensifying persecution of Jews in Europe from the latter half of the 19th century, that coexistence headed toward collapse when a movement arose that sought the building of a Jewish state in Palestine.Following the outbreak of the First World War, in anticipation of controlling the Middle East, the UK(5)made conflicting commitments to Arabs and Jews regarding Palestine.Consequently, when the influx of Jews to the region increased sharply following the Great War, conflict with the Arabs who were the local inhabitants deepened and the (6)Palestine question emerged.Subsequently, the founding of Israel and repeated Arab-Israeli conflicts(7)gave rise to a large number of refugees.
Question 4
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the region referred to in the underlined portion (4).
４
(1)In this region, which was under Roman rule, Moses criticized the existing Jewish religion.
(2)The Umayyad Caliphate designated Jerusalem as its capital.
(3)Christians built the Dome of the Rock, as they deemed Jerusalem to be a holy place.
(4)During the reign of the Rashidun Caliphate, Jerusalem came under the rule of Muslim powers.
Question 5
The following sentences concern the commitments referred to in the underlined portion (5).From (1)-(4) below, choose the correct combination of words that should be inserted into the gaps marked (a) and (b).
５
While promising independence to the Arabs in the (a), the UK agreed to the building of a "national home" for the Jewish people in Palestine in the (b), and also concluded a secret agreement with France and Russia to divide up Arab territory.
(1)a―Hussein-McMahon Correspondenceb―Balfour Declaration
(2)a―Sykes-Picot Agreementb―Balfour Declaration
(3)a―Balfour Declarationb―Hussein-McMahon Correspondence
(4)a―Hussein-McMahon Correspondenceb―Sykes-Picot Agreement
Question 6
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one incorrect sentence concerning the underlined portion (6).
６
(1)The United Nations adopted a proposal to divide up Palestine.
(2)The Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) carried out activities aimed at building a Palestinian state.
(3)Under the rule of President Nasser, Egypt concluded a peace treaty with Israel.
(4)The Palestine Liberation Organization (PLO) and Israel signed the Declaration of Principles on Interim Self-Government Arrangements.
Question 7
From (1)-(4) below, choose the sentence that is correct in regard to the specific one of the multiple Arab-Israeli conflicts causing the issue referred to in the underlined portion (7), which gave rise to the flows of refugees shown in the map below.The diagonally-shaded area indicates the area under Israeli rule immediately after the conflict in question.
７
(1)In the midst of this conflict, Araboil-producing countries commenced their oil strategy.
(2)Along with Israel, the United States of America invaded Egypt, which had declared that it would nationalize the Suez Canal.
(3)The Jews founded a country in Palestine and went to war with the Arab nations that opposed this.
(4)Israel carried out preemptive strikes on Arab nations and occupied part of the Sinai Peninsula, Syria and Jordan.
CIn multi-ethnic nations, consideration is sometimes given to a nation configuration known as a federal system, as one means of seeking coexistence between the various ethnic groups.For example, at the end of the 19th century, in its "Brunner Programm", the Social Democratic Party of Austria advocated reorganizing Austria, which was the part of (8)Austria-Hungary to the west of the Leitha River, into a democratic federation of its various ethnic groups.With regard to the federal system as a means of coexistence between ethnic groups, (9)Yugoslavia, Czechoslovakia and other such federations that were (10)socialist states collapsed at the end of the 20th century, leading to doubts about their effectiveness.However, as was the case in (11)Belgium, decentralization gradually progressed from the 1970s and it declared in its constitution that it was a federal state, when making constitutional amendments in 1993.
Question 8
The map below shows the distribution of the most populous ethnic groups in each region before the First World War in the country referred to in the underlined portion (8).Based on this map, from (1)-(4) below, choose the most appropriate sentence to describe the territory in each country after the First World War.
８
(1)All of the regions in which ethnic Czech citizens were distributed became Czechoslovakian territory.
(2)All of the regions in which ethnic Slovenian citizens were distributed became Italian territory.
(3)All of the regions in which ethnic German citizens were distributed became Austrian territory.
(4)All of the regions in which ethnic Hungarian citizens were distributed became Hungarian territory.
Question 9
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the history of the regions that formerly comprised Yugoslavia, in regard to the underlined portion (9).
９
(1)Bosnia and Herzegovina became independent of Austria-Hungary as a result of the Congress of Berlin (1878).
(2)The assassination [of Archduke Franz Ferdinand of Austria] in Sarajevo was the trigger for the First World War.
(3)The dictatorial regime of Ceausescu was imposed during the final years of the socialist regime.
(4)The civil war began when the Republic of Serbia declared its independence.
Question 10
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (10).
10
(1)During the Second World War, the Soviet Union sought to promote the spread of socialist revolution in the countries of Western Europe via Cominform.
(2)The Mongolian People's Republic came into existence at the beginning of the 1950s.
(3)After the Second World War, the Berlin blockade by the United States of America triggered the formation of the German Democratic Republic.
(4)The Castro regime, which was formed as a result of the Cuban Revolution, declared its adherence to socialism at the beginning of the 1960s.
Question 11
From (1)-(4) below, choose the correct combination of "correct" and "incorrect" in regard to the following sentences a and b concerning the country referred to in the underlined portion (11).
11
aDuring the First World War, the armed forces of the Allies invaded this country.
bDuring the Second World War, the armed forces of the Axis powers invaded this country.
(1)a- Correctb- Correct
(2)a- Correctb- Incorrect
(3)a- Incorrectb- Correct
(4)a- Incorrectb- Incorrect
[2]
Maps provide a good reflection of people's scope of activity and perspectives on the world at the time they were created.Read the following sentences A-C, which relate to the making of maps and their historical backdrop, and answer the questions (Questions 1-10) below.
(25 points)
AIn ancientGreece and Rome, attempts were made to create the most accurate map of the world possible.The picture below shows a map believed to have originated from (1), who lived in Alexandria in about the 2nd century.In the Middle Ages, the map created by (1) was forgotten and "mappae mundi" [maps of the world], which projected the Christian perspective on the world, came to be drawn up.However, in the 13th century, maps for practical use began to be made in Italy, as a result of the development of commerce.Subsequently, the map created by (1) was rediscovered during the (2)Renaissance period and disseminated through printing; in addition, as a result of such developments as the advent of the (3)Age of Discovery, attempts to create accurate maps began in earnest in Europe.
Question 1
The figure referred to as (1) is renowned for having systematized the geocentric model, which later had a major impact on astronomy in Europe.From (1)-(4) below, choose the correct name of that figure.
12
(1)Plutarch
(2)Ptolemy
(3)Euclid
(4)Pythagoras
Question 2
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (2).
13
(1)The House of Medici in Venice is renowned for having been a patron of Renaissance culture.
(2)Boccaccio was a leading painter of the Renaissance period.
(3)Cervantes, who wrote Don Quixote, was a leading writer in Spain during the Renaissance.
(4)Rabelais satirized the corruption of the Church and clergy in In Praise of Folly.
Question 3
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one incorrect sentence concerning the underlined portion (3).
14
(1)Magallanes (Magellan) sailed south on the Atlantic at the behest of the Portuguese king.
(2)Toscanelli's theory of the spherical Earth influenced the voyages of Columbus.
(3)InfanteHenrique of Portugal dispatched expeditions to the west coast of Africa.
(4)Columbus received support from QueenIsabella of Spain.
BMany missionaries from the Society of Jesus arrived in (4)Ming-and-Qing-dynastyChina, and the maps that they made had a major impact on the subsequent development of geography in China.In the 18th century, missionaries who had received orders from the (5)Kangxi Emperor were at the heart of efforts to create a number of partial maps, including maps of the dominion of the Qing dynasty and adjacent regions; these were compiled into a map covering a single scroll and presented to the emperor.This map was called the (6)Huang Yu Quan Lan Tu [Map of the Emperor's Territory] by the Kangxi Emperor and formed the basis of the maps made during the reign of the Yongzheng and Qianlong Emperors.The picture below shows a partial view from the Huang Yu Quan Lan Tu, which was published once more in the first half of the 20th century, using surviving copper plates of the map.
Question 4
From (1)-(4) below, choose the most appropriate sentence that describes scholarship and culture during the Ming and Qing periods in regard to the underlined portion (4).
15
(1)The Yongle Emperor ordered the compilation of the Siku Quanshu [The Complete Library in the Four Branches of Literature], which was an official commentary on the Confucian classics.
(2)Gu Yanwu developed the doctrine advocated by Qian Daxin and established it as kaozheng xue [evidential scholarship].
(3)Manuals and technical books about industrial technology and pharmacology were written during the Ming period.
(4)The novel Hong Lou Meng [Dream of the Red Chamber] was written during the Ming period.
Question 5
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes matters that occurred during the reign of the emperor referred to in the underlined portion (5).
16
(1)The Junjichu [Grand Council] was established and became the top political body.
(2)The Qing seized Beijing and made it their capital.
(3)Amherst was sent to the Qing court as the UK's envoy.
(4)Proselytizing by missionaries other than those from the Society of Jesus was prohibited.
Question 6
From (1)-(4) below, choose the correct combination of "correct" and "incorrect" in regard to the following sentences a and b concerning the map referred to in underlined portion (6).
17
aIt is a map drawn up on the basis of actual measurements.
bIt is a map of the whole world, including the African continent and the Americas.
(1)a- Correctb- Correct
(2)a- Correctb- Incorrect
(3)a- Incorrectb- Correct
(4)a- Incorrectb- Incorrect
Question 7
From (1)-(4) below, choose the most appropriate sentence that describes the history of the Shandong Peninsula, which is shown on the map.
18
(1)During the Warring States period, the Zhao state made this peninsula their domain.
(2)During the 2nd century BCE, Emperor Wu of Han established the Lelang Commandery on this peninsula.
(3)During the 10th century, the Liao held the Sixteen Prefectures, which were located on this peninsula.
(4)At the end of the 19th century, Germany leased Jiaozhou Bay [the Kiautschou Bay concession].
CMaps were revised in response to changes in the territory of each state.After conquering Siberia, maps were drawn up in Russia based on new geographical knowledge.Subsequently, as well as (7)advancing to the banks of the Heilong River (Amur River) and the Pacific coast, Russia also (8)invaded Central Asia.Thus, Russia grew to become a large empire.After the collapse of the Russian Empire, the (9)Soviet Union, which was formed in 1922, progressively reunified the majority of the territory of the former Russian Empire under the socialist system.This realm occupied just under one-sixth of all the land in the world.However, following the 1991dismantling of the Soviet Union, many independent nations were formed in former Soviet realms and maps underwent major revisions.
Question 8
From (1)-(4) below, choose which of the letters a-d on the map below corresponds most closely to the location of the place whose name was used in the name of a treaty concluded in the latter half of the 19th century between Russia and the Qing court, in relation to the underlined portion (7).
19
(1)a
(2)b
(3)c
(4)d
Question 9
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes Russia's invasion of Central Asia in the latter half of the 19th century in regard to the underlined portion (8).
20
(1)It fought the Safavid dynasty concerning national borders and acquired territory,
(2)It merged with the Kipchak Khanate.
(3)It subjugated the three khanates of Bukhara, Khiva and Kokand.
(4)It destroyed the Ilkhanate.
Question 10
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the country referred to in the underlined portion (9).
21
(1)After the formation of this country, Japan began the War of Intervention, as it feared the spread of revolution.
(2)The United States of America recognized this country in the 1930s.
(3)The three Baltic states were involved in the formation of this country.
(4)Romania became independent from this country.
[3]
The invention of writing has had extremely great significance over the course of human history.Read the following texts A-C, which relate to the history and culture of writing, and answer the questions (Questions 1-10) below.
(24 points)
AThe photograph below shows a piece of papyrus with an order that it is believed was issued to a Romansoldier in 33 BCE by (1)QueenCleopatra, the last pharaoh of the Ptolemaic dynasty of Egypt.The inscription written on it in the Greek alphabet means "make it happen".(2)In ancient societies, various materials were used to write down a range of characters.For example, in Athens at the end of the 6th century BCE, in the system established as a result of the reforms by Cleisthenes in order to (A), (B) were used to vote.
Question 1
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes the political situation in Egypt and Rome at the time when the figure referred to in the underlined portion (1) was the queen of Egypt.
22
(1)The Second Triumvirate was formed by Octavian, Mark Antony and Crassus.
(2)Rome seized Sicily from Egypt and made it a Roman province.
(3)The conflict between Octavian and Mark Antony deepened over the status of Pompey's successor.
(4)Cleopatra and Mark Antony had a cooperative relationship.
Question 2
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that incorrectly describes characters and written records in regard to the underlined portion (2).
23
(1)The Rosetta Stone has a section written in the Greek alphabet.
(2)Cuneiform script was mainly inscribed on clay tablets, but there are also examples of its use in inscriptions on monuments.
(3)The Book of the Dead is written on papyrus in the Aramaic alphabet.
(4)The Indus script is engraved on seals, among other things, but it has not yet been deciphered.
Question 3
From (1)-(4) below, choose the correct combination of words that should be inserted into the gaps marked (A) and (B).
24
(1)A-prevent tyrannyB-copper plates
(2)A-prevent tyrannyB-shards of pottery
(3)A-elect a tribuneB-copper plates
(4)A-elect a tribuneB-shards of pottery
BAt present, apart from Vietnam, which uses the Roman alphabet, the countries of continental Southeast Asia each have (3)their own script that is used to write their national language (see the diagram below).However, all of these scripts are similar, because they are derived from the script of southern India, which illustrates the fact that Indian culture was assimilated in Southeast Asia.If we look at the origins of these characters, we can trace them back to the Brahmi script that was already being used in (4)India in the 3rd century BCE.Southern Indianscript was also passed on to (5)the islands of Southeast Asia, including the Malay Peninsula, and central and southern Vietnam, but when Islam spread to these regions, the Arabic alphabet came to be used to write their languages.
Question 4
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one correct sentence concerning the various types of script that have been used in parts of Asia, in relation to the underlined portion (3).
25
(1)The Tibetan alphabet was based on Indianscript.
(2)The Old Uyghur alphabet is the oldest nomadicscript.
(3)Hunminjeongeum (hangul) was created during the Goryeo period.
(4)Tangut script was devised to express the Mongolian language.
Question 5
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (4).
26
(1)Siddhartha Gautama founded Buddhism.
(2)Ashoka aimed to rule on the basis of dharma.
(3)Kanishka was a patron of Buddhism and gathered together Buddhist scriptures.
(4)Chandragupta II ruled the whole of northern India.
Question 6
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (5).
27
(1)The Mataram Sultanate flourished as the last Hindu kingdom on Java.
(2)During the Sailendra dynasty, Theravada Buddhism (Hinayana Buddhism) flourished.
(3)Islam was the faith of the Malacca Sultanate.
(4)The Islamization of this region began with the southern Philippine Islands.
C(6)Latin, which was the language of the Romans, continued to be used as a written language, even in the Germanic tribal states that were formed from antiquity through to the beginning of the Middle Ages.It is said that it was in the 12th or 13th century that the people in each part of Western Europe began frequently to use Latin characters to express in writing the words that they spoke on a daily basis.When this development took place, (7)each area's poems and stories, which had previously been conveyed orally, began to be written down using this alphabet and began to become fixed.Eventually, the custom of creating documents in (8)languages other than Latin spread in official fields, such as government and law.From among these languages emerged some that became the official languages of modern states, forming the cornerstone of each national culture.(9)In the 18th and 19th centuries, many works began to be produced that were described as national literature.
Question 7
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the underlined portion (6).
28
(1)Hesiod wrote Works and Days, which describes the life of a farmer, in Latin.
(2)Tacitus wrote Commentarii de Bello Gallico [Commentaries on the Gallic War], which depicted the social lives of the Germanic peoples in the final years of the Roman Empire, in Latin.
(3)Academic books in Arabic were translated into Latin and had a major impact on scholarship in Europe during the Middle Ages.
(3)In the Byzantine Empire, Latin continued to be used as the sole official language.
Question 8
In regard to the underlined portion (7), from (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that incorrectly describes literature in the world of Western Europe.
29
(1)In the courts, minstrels recited chansons de geste [songs of heroic deeds] and courtly love poems.
(2)In Italy, Dante wrote the Divine Comedy in the dialect of the Tuscany region.
(3)In Great Britain, the Matter of Britain was compiled, depicting the activities of Charlemagne and his warriors.
(4)The Nibelungenlied [The Lay of the Nibelungs] was compiled on the basis of the heroic legendary tales of the Germanic peoples,
Question 9
In regard to the underlined portion (8), from (1)-(4) below, choose the correct word that fits into the gap marked (A) in the sentences below concerning the origins of English.
30
Since ancient times, a variety of ethnic groups have repeatedly invaded the island of Britain, so English, which is a Germanic language, has been influenced by various languages over the course of centuries.Classifying the vocabulary of modern English by its etymology, as well as Ancient Greek and Latin, the influence of the language of (A) is particularly conspicuous.AIt is believed that the massive influx of words from (A) began after the conqueror who came from (A) in the latter half of the 11th century established a comparatively strong hold over the throne.
(1)Germany
(2)France
(3)Denmark
(4)the Netherlands
Question 10
From (1)-(4) below, choose the sentence in which the word with a wavy line below it is correct in regard to European literature in the 18th and 19th centuries, in relation to the underlined portion (9).
31
(1)Classicism, which prized the supremacy of individuality and emotion, and revered history and the traditions of ethnic culture, flourished from the end of the 18th century to the first half of the 19th century.
(2)In Germany during the first half of the 19th century, Heine, who was called a revolutionary poet, wrote works such as Buch der Lieder [Book of Songs].
(3)In Russia during the first half of the 19th century, Gorky published works such as his masterpiece Eugene Onegin, thereby establishing the country's national literature.
(4)Romanticism emerged in the latter half of the 19th century, against the background of the maturing of civil society and the rapid development of science and technology.
[4]
There have been various approaches to families and relatives in different regions and time periods.Read the following texts A-C, which relate to families and relatives throughout history, and answer the questions (Questions 1-10) below.
(24 points)
AIn China, familial groups called clans could be widely seen.Clans are groups organized by people who have a common ancestor and believe themselves to be linked by blood ties via the paternal line.They had the same family name and carried out activities such as conducting ancestral rituals and compiling genealogical books (records of the family line of a clan).Moreover, there was a fundamental rule of surname exogamy, which meant that a man and a (1)woman with the same family name could not marry.(2)Clans existed from ancient times, but it is certainly not the case that they continued unchanged throughout the centuries.For example, during the Qing period, (3)migration to the outlying regions of China and development progressed against the background of a sharp increase in the population, and new clans and groups of migrants from the same village were formed in the fluid migrant society, in order to deal with the unstable social environment.
Question 1
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one correct sentence concerning matters pertaining to women in Chinese history, in relation to the underlined portion (1).
32
(1)Empress Wu Zetian was enthroned as empress regnant and named her dynasty the Zhou dynasty.
(2)Emperor Xuanzong of Tang favored Yang Guifei, causing the Huang Chao Rebellion.
(3)Wang Xizhi, who lived during the Eastern Jin dynasty, is known for Admonitions of the Court Instructress, which is a pictorial scroll featuring lessons for women of the court.
(4)The Taiping Heavenly Kingdom forced women to bind their feet.
Question 2
In regard to the underlined portion (2), from (1)-(3) below, choose the one sentence that incorrectly describes clans and families from the Western Zhou through to the Warring States period.
33
(1)Clans sought unity via zong-fa [clan law].
(2)Clans were controlled by the state by means of the sanchang system of local administration.
(3)Confucians attached importance to the practice of family morality in the form of filial piety and respect for one's elders.
(4)Mohism advocated philanthropy (impartial care) that went beyond the family.
Question 3
In regard to the underlined portion (3), from (1)-(4) below, choose the correct combination of "correct" and "incorrect" in regard to the following sentences a and b concerning migration and development in Chinese history.
34
aDuring the Eastern Jin period, development progressed in the Jiangnan region, where the number of migrants had increased.
bThroughout the Ming period, migration overseas was encouraged.
(1)a- Correctb- Correct
(2)a- Correctb- Incorrect
(3)a- Incorrectb- Correct
(4)a- Incorrectb- Incorrect
BIndian(4)Dharmasastra literature has discussed the "joint family" as the basic form of family.The joint family is a group formed through the paternal line, consisting of members spanning several generations, with rights to family property.However, it was the wealthy class, consisting mainly of the highest caste, which took as its ideal the joint family consisting of multiple households living together under the head of the household, and put this into practice.During the British colonial period, joint families were contrasted with (5)Western family and inter-gender relationships as a family type peculiar to Hindus, and were frequently praised from a (6)nationalistic standpoint.The strength of the family ties that were emphasized not only by Hindus but also in general in South Asia(7)is thought to be one of the factors that gave rise to the famous female politicians who emerged from this region.
Question 4
The underlined portion (4) refers to the generic term for literature that indicates the code of conduct for each varna [caste].From (1)-(4) below, choose the most appropriate phrase concerning the name of the literature included in this.
35
(1)The Code of Hammurabi
(2)The Mahabharata
(3)Manusmrti [The Laws of Manu]
(4)The Avesta
Question 5
In regard to the underlined portion (5), from (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that incorrectly describes women's rights and changes in their status in the West.
36
(1)Women's suffrage began in the United States of America after the Second World War.
(2)During the Industrial Revolution in Great Britain, women and children were employed in factories as a cheap workforce.
(3)Rosa Luxemburg was active as a leader of the Spartacus League.
(4)During the First World War, the Westerncountries participating in the war included some countries in which women had advanced into the workplace.
Question 6
From (1)-(6) below, in regard to the underlined portion (6), choose the option showing the correct sequence of events in phrases a-c below, starting with the oldest first, concerning colonial rule and nationalist movements in South Asia.
37
aThe beginning of the passive resistance movementbThe formation of the All-India Muslim League
cThe promulgation of the Partition of Bengal
(1)a→b→c
(2)a→c→b
(3)b→a→c
(4)b→c→a
(5)c→a→b
(6)c→b→a
Question 7
In regard to the underlined portion (7), many female politicians in South Asia are the wives or daughters of powerful politicians; for example, Indira Gandhi was the daughter of the figure in the photograph (see the photograph below), who was the first Prime Minister of India.From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that is correct in regard to the figure in the photograph.
38
(1)He announced the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence along with Mao Zedong.
(2)The Sino-Indian War occurred during his term as Prime Minister.
(3)He opposed the resolution to demand Purna Swaraj (complete self-rule).
(4)He participated in the founding of the Indian National Congress.
CToday, research into social history is advancing and details of the lives of the common people of early modernFrance are emerging.During this period, it was not easy to live.It was not uncommon for women to lose their lives in childbirth and the infant mortality rate was also high, with only half of all babies reaching the age of 20.In an ordinary year, the number of live births was higher than the number of deaths, but due to the deterioration of the food situation as a result of poor weather or (8)war, as well as outbreaks of epidemics, the country was often beset by (9)population crises, in which a large number of deaths occurred.Approximately 80% of people were (10)farmers and they generally married neighbors in similar circumstances to themselves, but their family lives were constrained by these harsh conditions of existence.
Question 8
From (1)-(4) below, choose the one sentence that correctly describes matters concerning war in Europe in regard to the underlined portion (8).
39
(1)Joan of Arc was active during the Wars of the Roses.
(2)Louis XIII began the War of the Palatine Succession.
(3)Great Britain won the Anglo-Dutch Wars in the 17th century.
(4)The Italian War of Unification occurred because of the problem of succession to the Spanish throne.
Question 9
In relation to the underlined portion (9), the following graph shows the number of baptisms (births), marriages and burials in a particular region of France, as well as an index of the price of wheat; one can see that a population crisis occurred on two occasions.From (1)-(6) below, choose the one correct combination of words to describe lines a-c.

Question 10
In regard to the underlined portion (10), from (1)-(4) below, choose the most appropriate sentence that describes events that are believed to have had a major impact on the lives of farmers in Europe.
41
(1)In the middle of the 10th century, a major outbreak of the Black Death (plague) caused a workforce shortage in agricultural communities, and the status of farmers improved.
(2)Agricultural productivity improved and both village communities and cities prospered, so the feudal society collapsed between the 11th and 12th centuries.
(3)In Prussia, the emancipation of the serfs took place during the reign of Joseph II.
(4)In Great Britain, the farmers who had lost their land during the second enclosure movement provided a source of manpower for new industries.
